questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of yellow vaginal discharge, itching, and pain with urination for the past 6 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently; she has been taking an oral contraceptive for the past 2 years. She has no history of serious illness or sexually transmitted diseases. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vagina and cervix with well-defined punctate hemorrhages and foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.8. Bimanual examination is unremarkable. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common cause of sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. Infection with chlamydia is often asymptomatic. If symptoms appear, they typically include (muco)purulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding. Furthermore, physical examination of the cervix often causes bleeding, whereas the bimanual examination of this patient was unremarkable.

B) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative diplococci indicate infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonorrhea). The disease is transmitted sexually and is usually asymptomatic in women. If symptoms arise, they typically include purulent, creamy vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding but no erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface; these cells are characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. The vaginal discharge in bacterial vaginosis also has pH > 4.5. Unlike in this patient, bacterial vaginosis usually manifests without vulvovaginal erythema and the discharge is white or grey-colored and has a fishy odor.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae are loosely filamentous forms of fungi assumed by many yeasts, particularly Candida albicans, during growth. They are commonly seen on wet mounts of patients with vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis), which are associated with odorless, white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge that may resemble cottage cheese. Pregnancy, antibiotic use, and immunosuppression are predisposing factors for vaginal thrush. Even though this patient had a course of amoxicillin, her discharge is foul-smelling and yellow-green, making a candidal infection very unlikely. Also, vaginal pH is typically normal (4–4.5) in vulvovaginal candidiasis.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

E) CORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile protozoan with multiple flagella. Patients typically have foul-smelling, frothy, purulent vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Transmission of this disease occurs through unprotected sex. Most patients remain asymptomatic. Treatment consists of oral metronidazole or tinidazole for the patient and sexual partner(s).

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.
questions.hint: Vaginal and cervical erythema with punctate hemorrhages (strawberry cervix) along with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with an elevated pH value is consistent with trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of vaginal discharge. She has no pain or pruritus. Menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. She had a normal Pap smear 3 months ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows malodorous, gray vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.0. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a cause of vaginitis, specifically aerobic vaginitis. E. coli vaginitis is characterized by vaginal discharge and an increase in the vaginal pH (> 4.5). However, discharge caused by E. coli is usually odorless, yellowish, and manifests with pruritus.

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea. Gonorrhea also manifests with vaginal discharge, but the discharge is typically odorless, purulent, and creamy. The patient is also lacking symptoms of dysuria, dyspareunia, and intermenstrual bleeding, which are typical accompanying features.

C) CORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is an anaerobic bacterium that causes bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is usually asymptomatic, but may manifest with gray, malodorous vaginal discharge. There are two characteristic diagnostic findings of BV: clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria) seen on a wet mount preparation and a positive amine test (sometimes referred to as the “whiff test”). The amine test consists of applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with vaginal discharge, and is positive if this causes a fishy or amine odor.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in the US and a common cause of female infertility. C. trachomatis infection is often asymptomatic, but if discharge occurs, it is usually odorless and purulent. Clue cells are not associated with C. trachomatis, and instead it is usually diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification tests.

E) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Even though C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically odorless, white, and crumbly, and the vaginal pH would be normal (< 4.5). Additional symptoms of infection with C. albicans include intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

F) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite and one of the etiologic agents of vulvovaginitis. Although T. vaginalis would cause malodorous vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5, the discharge is usually yellow-green and frothy. Additionally, vulvovaginitis due to T. vaginalis manifests with pruritus, and the microscopic examination of the discharge would instead show flagellated protozoa.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of trichomonas vaginalis trophozoites (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

The protozoan appears oval-shaped with flagella (examples indicated by arrowheads) and a nucleus (green overlay) located at the anterior end.
questions.hint: Malodorous, gray vaginal discharge, an increased vaginal pH, and clue cells on microscopy are consistent with bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 5-month history of painful sexual intercourse. She also reports vaginal pruritus and occasional spotting. She has no pain with urination. She had two urinary tract infections over the past 3 years that resolved with oral antibiotic therapy. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Her last menstrual period was 8 months ago. She is sexually active with her husband and has two children. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years. Current medications include ramipril, metformin, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows decreasing labial fat pad, receding pubic hair, and clear vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal drug recommended for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Although this infection may manifest with pruritus and an odorless vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually white and curd-like (“cottage cheese” appearance). Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis would also cause dysuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is a second-line antifungal drug recommended for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Although this infection may manifest with pruritus and an odorless vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually white and curd-like (“cottage cheese” appearance). Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis would also cause dysuria.

C) CORRECT:

Topical estrogen creams effectively alleviate symptoms of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is thought to be caused by low estrogen levels after menopause. Similar symptoms can also occur postpartum or during breastfeeding due to estrogen deficiency. Moisturizers and vaginal lubricants are an alternative for mild cases and can also be used as an adjunct to hormone treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is recommended as the first-line treatment for Gardnerella vaginalis and Trichomonas vaginalis infections. Although both infections may manifest with vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually foul-smelling and not clear. These infections would also not explain a decreasing labial fat pad or receding pubic hair.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used for the treatment of lichen planus. Although genital lichen planus may also cause dyspareunia and mostly affects women over 50 years of age, it is frequently accompanied by several symptoms such as vulvar pain, pruritus, and burning. Moreover, it is commonly associated with cutaneous or oral lichen planus.
questions.hint: Receding pubic hair and decreasing labial fat pads are typical symptoms for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. Her mother says she has been having trouble sleeping for 3 weeks because of pruritus in her genital area. The girl has otherwise been feeling well. She is at the 45th percentile for height and 51st percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and perianal region. There is no vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae on a potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount of a perineal or vaginal swab is diagnostic of vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC). VVC may occur in pediatric patients, but it occurs more often in children who are still in diapers (candidal diaper dermatitis), which is not the case with this patient. VVC is characterized by white discharge and erythema of the intertriginous folds with “satellite” papules, neither of which are seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Perianal cellophane-tape examination (i.e., a tape test) is the diagnostic test for Enterobius vermicularis infection. At night, female worms migrate from the colon to the anal opening, where they deposit eggs, which cause perianal and vulvar irritation and pruritus. The test is conducted by applying a transparent piece of cellophane tape to the anal opening early in the morning; any ova of Enterobius vermicularis will then stick to the tape. By pressing the sticky side of the tape against a slide, anything picked up by the tape can be examined for the presence of eggs. If the tape test confirms pinworm infection, treatment of the entire household with albendazole or mebendazole is indicated to prevent reinfection.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the colon

A worm is visible in the colon (green overlay). The surrounding mucosa's surface and vascular pattern appear normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Wet mount microscopy is used to diagnose suspected trichomoniasis or bacterial vaginosis. While a burning sensation in the vulvovaginal area is a typical feature of trichomoniasis, a foul-smelling, yellow-green discharge is usually present as well. Bacterial vaginosis does not commonly cause vulvovaginal pruritus and instead presents with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. The absence of vaginal discharge in this patient makes these infections unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Sexual abuse, and therefore STDs, are a concern in minors presenting with vulvovaginitis. However, in this patient, the absence of genital lesions or evidence of trauma make sexual abuse unlikely. Moreover, infections with Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea are most often asymptomatic or manifest with symptoms of cervicitis (e.g., vaginal discharge or pain, bleeding on manipulation), urethritis (e.g., urethral discharge, dysuria, and urinary frequency), or pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., fever, abdominal/pelvic pain). Nocturnal vulvar pruritus and erythema of the vulva and perianal region would not be expected.
Image Description:

Purulent discharge can be seen on this patient's vulva on external genital examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Stool microscopy can be used to diagnose gastrointestinal infections with protozoans (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica) or helminths (e.g., roundworms, tapeworms, and hookworms). In helminth infection, worm eggs (ova) can be detected in the stool. Enterobiasis, however, cannot be diagnosed reliably with stool microscopy because the ova of Enterobius vermicularis are almost never shed in feces. Instead, the gravid female worms migrate to the anal opening at night and deposit the ova there.
questions.hint: Anogenital pruritus (especially at night) in a toddler or preschooler is a classic symptom of enterobiasis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for the past 3 days. She has no dysuria, dyspareunia, pruritus, or burning. The patient is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She often douches after sexual intercourse. Pelvic examination shows thin and off-white vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.1. Wet mount examination shows that a quarter of vaginal epithelial cells are covered with small coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Treat the patient with ceftriaxone and doxycycline
Treat the patient and partners with metronidazole
Treat the patient and partners with ceftriaxone and doxycycline
Reassurance and follow-up in one week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and in patients with coinfection. Gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, vaginal pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia are common, together with a purulent, creamy discharge. However, this patient has no symptoms aside from a thin, off-white discharge. Additionally, if gonorrhea were present, treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days because of potentially severe complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, urethritis, and/or infertility. As doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy, a pregnancy test should be obtained before initiation of pharmacotherapy as this patient uses condoms inconsistently.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is indicated for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. However, as bacterial vaginosis is not a sexually transmitted infection, partner treatment is not necessary. Antibiotic treatment for both the patient and the partner is indicated in patients with infectious vulvovaginitis caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, such as trichomoniasis, which would manifest with a frothy, foul-smelling discharge with a pH ≥ 4.5 and flagellated protozoa on a wet mount.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Ketoconazole is indicated for vaginal candidiasis, which would manifest with severe pruritus as well as an odorless, curd-like discharge.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

D) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and in patients with coinfection. Treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days because of potentially severe complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, urethritis, and/or infertility. Gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, vaginal pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia are common, together with a purulent, creamy discharge. However, this patient has no symptoms aside from a thin, off-white discharge. As doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy, a pregnancy test should be obtained before initiation of pharmacotherapy as this patient uses condoms inconsistently.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance would be adequate if the patient did not have vaginal discharge and if bacterial vaginosis had been incidentally diagnosed during a routine check-up. Symptomatic bacterial vaginosis, however, does require treatment.

F) CORRECT:

Metronidazole is prescribed for anaerobic infections with pathogens such as Gardnerella vaginalis, the cause of bacterial vaginosis. Although sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis, this condition is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an imbalance of the vaginal flora resulting in overgrowth of Gardnerella bacteria (and a relative lack of the normally dominant lactobacilli). Another risk factor for this imbalance is vaginal douching, which this woman reports she does regularly. Bacterial vaginosis is commonly asymptomatic, but when symptomatic, individuals should receive treatment with either oral or topical metronidazole. As bacterial vaginosis is not an STI, there is no need for partner treatment. The CDC recommends that women who are being treated for bacterial vaginosis refrain from sexual activity or use condoms consistently and correctly as well as avoid douching, as it increases the risk of relapse.
Image Description:

Speculum view of the cervix with thin gray and milky discharge
questions.hint: Based on the color and pH value of the vaginal discharge and the wet mount showing clue cells, this patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Over the past 2 weeks, she has felt nauseous in the morning. She has also had vulvar itching and pain when urinating that started 5 days ago. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of macrosomia from gestational diabetes. Her gestational diabetes resolved after the child was born. She appears well. Ultrasound confirms fetal heart tones and an intrauterine pregnancy. Speculum examination shows a whitish chunky discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.2. A wet mount is performed and microscopic examination is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is an antibiotic used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis, but it is not appropriate for vulvovaginal candidiasis. Metronidazole should also be used with caution in the first trimester of pregnancy. Bacterial vaginosis is the most common vaginal infection in women and usually manifests with gray discharge with a fishy odor and is typically not associated with pruritus. Trichomoniasis usually manifests with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green, purulent discharge, pruritus, and dysuria. Wet mount in trichomoniasis shows protozoa with multiple flagella.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment with probiotics such as live lactobacilli (either oral or intravaginal) have not been shown to be effective in the treatment or prevention of vaginal yeast infections. Although it is common belief that ingestion or vaginal administration of live lactobacilli (e.g., in yogurt) can restore damaged vaginal flora and prevent vulvovaginal candidiasis, there is no evidence that women with recurrent vaginal yeast infection have a deficiency in lactobacilli.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole is an azole antifungal agent primarily used for the treatment of candidiasis. However, systemic azoles are typically avoided in pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, due to the increased risk of miscarriage and possible birth defects.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravaginal clindamycin is a treatment option for bacterial vaginosis, but it is not appropriate for vulvovaginal candidiasis. Bacterial vaginosis is the most common vaginal infection in women and usually manifests with gray discharge with a fishy odor and is typically not associated with pruritus.

E) CORRECT:

Intravaginal clotrimazole is a topical antifungal agent and the first-line treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis in pregnancy. Treatment primarily aims at symptom relief, as vulvovaginal candidiasis is not associated with adverse outcomes in pregnancy. While oral azoles are commonly used in uncomplicated infections, they are typically avoided during pregnancy, particularly during the first trimester. Complications associated with the use of oral azoles during pregnancy include miscarriage and birth defects such as abnormalities of the bones and heart.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.
questions.hint: The patient's presentation combined with the pseudohyphae and hyphae with budding yeast on wet mount indicate vulvovaginal candidiasis. In determining the most appropriate pharmacologic agent, the patient's pregnancy has to be taken into account.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of vaginal discharge for the past month. The discharge is foul-smelling and contains some blood. The patient sometimes has pain with urination. She has not had increased urinary frequency or abdominal pain. Topical vaginal cream application did not improve the patient's symptoms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She lives with her parents and attends a local daycare center. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the vulva and vaginal entrance shows an intact hymen, vaginal erythema with blood-tinged, foul-smelling discharge, and the tip of a white object. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the case of a vaginal foreign body, the object must be removed to avoid further genitourinary inflammation, superinfection, or complications like fistula formation. Toilet paper is a typical cause in toddlers who are still being potty trained and is likely the white object seen in this patient. Gentle irrigation of the vagina with saline solution or water in the outpatient setting is usually sufficient to dislodge the foreign body and is thus the first step in management.

In children presenting with a vaginal foreign body, the possibility of sexual abuse should always be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

A wet mount preparation is carried out when a bacterial vaginal infection is suspected. However, the discharge in this child is neither purulent nor typical of other bacterial infections (like bacterial vaginosis or trichomoniasis), and there are no signs of systemic infection (like fever, tachycardia). It is, therefore, unlikely that this is a typical bacterial vaginal infection, meaning a wet mount test would not be the most appropriate next step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

A colposcopy would be employed to visualize a foreign body in the vagina that was not visible under normal physical examination, or if it is a large body expected to have affected the cervix. This is not the case in this child. Moreover, considering the age of this child, a colposcopy would best be avoided because of the chance of hymenal injury and bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Vacuum suction or other minimally invasive gynecological procedures (like forceps-assisted removal) are indicated for the removal of foreign bodies from the genitourinary tract in adult patient groups. Such procedures should be avoided in prepubertal children to avoid damage to the vulvovaginal soft tissues and the intact hymen. The vulvovaginal mucosa in this age group is thin and fragile due to low estrogen levels and thin labial fat pads and is thus susceptible to injury from such procedures.

E) INCORRECT:

Bleeding from the genital tract in the setting of a vaginal foreign body should always raise suspicion for the possibility of child abuse. This patient's history does not suggest sexual abuse (repeated history of foreign object insertion, abusive parent, etc.). Child protective services (CPS) should only be alerted in cases with evidence of child abuse or the likelihood for abuse to take place.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral metronidazole is used to treat vulvovaginitis caused by either Gardnerella vaginalis (bacterial vaginosis) or Trichomonas vaginalis (trichomoniasis). Both of these infections are typically seen in adults. Bacterial vaginosis is associated with a gray or milky discharge with a fishy odor, whereas trichomoniasis exhibits a frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge. The age of this child, her discharge characteristics, and the source of infection (foreign body in genital tract) make these diagnoses unlikely.
questions.hint: This toddler's presentation suggests vulvovaginitis that appears to be caused by a vaginal foreign body.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She also noticed white vaginal discharge despite cleaning her genital area daily using a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is worried that she might have contracted a sexually transmitted disease after meeting her new boyfriend around one month ago. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient swims for the college swimming team. She had an intrauterine device implanted 3 months ago and does not use barrier protection. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and does not drink alcohol. Speculum examination shows an erythematous vagina covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4 and the microscopic image of a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking decreases the number of vaginal Lactobacillus species, has an antiestrogenic effect, and dysregulates immune function, making smokers more prone to bacterial vaginosis, which manifests with a gray or milky vaginal discharge that has a fishy odor. Discharge in candidal vulvovaginitis, on the contrary, is usually white, crumbly, and odorless. Smoking has not been shown to be a risk factor for vaginal yeast infection, although it is one for oral candidiasis in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with diabetes).

B) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

D) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 1-week-history of painful urination and urinary frequency. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F). There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase. A Gram stain does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is the yeast responsible for candidal vulvovaginitis, which can also present with dysuria, as seen in this patient. However, microscopic examination would typically show branching pseudohyphae with budding yeasts, unlike the findings here. Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis typically presents with a thick cottage cheese-like vaginal discharge, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea, which can also manifest with urethritis and vulvovaginitis, as seen in this patient. However, Gram stain would typically show gram-negative diplococci, as opposed to the findings here. While gonorrhea may be asymptomatic, it often manifests with purulent, creamy vaginal discharge.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)

The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of urinary tract infections (UTI) in adults. UTI caused by E. coli can also present with dysuria, urinary frequency, and a positive leukocyte esterase test, as seen here. However, gram stain of the urine would show gram-negative rods, as opposed to the findings here.

D) INCORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram-variable rod that causes bacterial vaginosis. Sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis although it is not considered an STI. Microscopic examination would show clue cells, as opposed to this patient's findings. Moreover, bacterial vaginosis is typically painless and may present with a gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor that this patient does not have.

E) CORRECT:

This patient likely has Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Although most cases are asymptomatic, patients can present with urethritis and/or vulvovaginitis, as seen here. Chlamydiae do not gram stain well because they are obligate intracellular bacteria that lack muramic acid in their cell wall. In the diagnosis of chlamydia infection, Giemsa stain or fluorescent antibody stain can be used to identify reticulate bodies (i.e., cytoplasmic inclusions.) PCR (nucleic acid amplification) is the gold standard diagnostic test for chlamydiae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (unknown magnification)

Cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (black arrows) show inclusion bodies (reticulate bodies, here in brown) under the microscope.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular bacteria that require cell culture, rather than growth medium, to grow. This characteristic is especially important for determining the best antibiotic for treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is the causative organism of Trichomonas vaginitis, a sexually transmitted disease that typically presents with dysuria. However, microscopic examination would show motile flagellated protozoa, as opposed to the findings here. Moreover, Trichomonas vaginitis classically presents with a yellow-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.
questions.hint: This sexually active patient presents with features of urethritis and vulvovaginitis (painful urination, positive leukocyte esterase) and a negative urine Gram stain. She likely has an infection with an organism that lacks muramic acid in the cell wall.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 3 days. She has been sexually active with three male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Physical exam shows thin grayish-white vaginal discharge. There is no erythema of the vaginal mucosa. The pH of the discharge is 5.9. Adding potassium hydroxide (KOH) to a mount containing vaginal discharge produces a fishy odor. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that causes chlamydia, the most common sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. While many cases are asymptomatic, chlamydia can present with an odorless and purulent cervical discharge; cervical friability; and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding. Although this patient has risk factors for chlamydia, she has no cervical bleeding during bimanual exam and a different description of vaginal discharge (color, smell, whiff).

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae are a morphological growth form of yeast. When associated with gynecological complaints, pseudohyphae typically refer to Candida albicans, which causes vulvovaginal candidiasis. The main features of vulvovaginal candidiasis are dyspareunia, vaginal pruritus, and odorless vaginal discharge resembling cottage cheese with normal pH (4–4.5). This patient is unlikely to have vaginal candidiasis because her discharge is grayish-white and malodorous, and she has an increased pH.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

C) CORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is a pleomorphic, gram-variable rod that causes bacterial vaginosis, which is consistent with this patient's findings of characteristic thin grayish-white vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5 that has a fishy odor when KOH is added (positive whiff-amine test). The absence of vaginal pain or erythema further supports this diagnosis. Bacterial vaginosis typically develops when the pH of the vagina rises above 4.5, which allows G. vaginalis to multiply and results in the characteristic malodorous vaginal discharge. Predisposing factors include a shift in vaginal flora (e.g., douching decreases Lactobacillus that maintain vaginal pH between 3.8 and 4.5), the release of amines from increased bacterial degradation of proteins, and/or increased sexual activity (as the pH of semen is between 7.2 and 7.8).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum is a spirochete that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis presents as a chancre whereas secondary syphilis manifests with condyloma lata, lymphadenopathy, and polymorphic rash that classically involves the palms and soles. Although this patient has risk factors for syphilis, syphilis cannot explain her abnormal vaginal discharge.

E) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonorrhea, a common sexually transmitted disease. While gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic in women, it can manifest as purulent vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding. Although this patient has risk factors for gonorrhea, she has a different vaginal discharge description (odorless, creamy, pale with negative Whiff test).

F) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile, and flagellated protozoan that causes trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis presents with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Although this patient has malodorous vaginal discharge with increased vaginal pH, the vaginal discharge associated with trichomoniasis has different characteristics than that of this patient. Furthermore, the wet mount would show motile, flagellated organisms in trichomoniasis.
questions.hint: Clue cells are an important histological finding for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female comes to the office because of a 3-week history of vaginal discharge and itching despite cleaning her genitals with a vaginal douche. Her last menstrual period was one week ago. She is sexually active with her new boyfriend. She has an intrauterine device and does not use barrier protection. She was treated for a sore throat infection one month ago. Speculum examination shows erythema around the vaginal introitus and copious white discharge. Vaginal pH is 4.3 and a KOH test shows multiple pseudohyphae on microscopy. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy is a risk factor for vulvovaginal candidiasis. It results from high levels of glycogen, estrogen, and progesterone, which favors colonization with C. albicans by providing carbon. However, this patient has an intrauterine device, and her last menstrual period was a week ago, making a pregnancy very unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Systemic antibiotic treatment (e.g., oral, intravenous) causes suppression of normal vaginal bacterial flora, which promotes C. albicans overgrowth. Antibiotics increase the incidence of symptomatic vulvovaginitis and vaginal colonization with C. albicans in asymptomatic patients. A normal vaginal pH (< 4.5) and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination of a KOH test confirms the diagnosis. This patient was likely treated with antibiotics for bacterial pharyngitis.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

C) INCORRECT:

Vaginal douching is a risk factor for bacterial vaginosis because it decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in vaginal pH. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis. This patient's normal vaginal pH (< 4.5) and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination of a KOH test are inconsistent with bacterial vaginosis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices (IUDs) may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), such as trichomoniasis and chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of a Candida infection.

questions.text: A previously healthy 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of vaginal discharge. She has no pain or pruritus. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Pelvic examination shows a malodorous gray vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis. It is usually asymptomatic but may present with vaginal discharge as seen in this patient. There are two characteristic diagnostic findings: Clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria) seen on a wet mount preparation and a positive amine test. The amine test (sometimes referred to as the “whiff test”) consists of applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with vaginal discharge, and is positive if this causes a fishy or amine odor.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichomoniasis is caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis. Although trichomoniasis would cause a malodorous vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually yellow-green and frothy. Additionally, trichomoniasis typically presents with pruritus, and the microscopic examination of the discharge would instead show flagellated protozoa.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases in the US and a common cause of female infertility. C. trachomatis infection is often asymptomatic, but if discharge occurs, it is usually odorless and purulent. Clue cells are not associated with chlamydia, and instead it is usually diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification tests.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (unknown magnification)

Cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (black arrows) show inclusion bodies (reticulate bodies, here in brown) under the microscope.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular bacteria that require cell culture, rather than growth medium, to grow. This characteristic is especially important for determining the best antibiotic for treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonorrhea is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It also manifests with vaginal discharge, but the discharge is typically odorless, purulent, and creamy. The patient also lacks symptoms of dysuria, dyspareunia, and intermenstrual bleeding, which are typical accompanying features. Microscopic examination would show gram-negative diplococci.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)

The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum. Primary syphilis does not cause vaginal discharge but instead presents with a painless chancre and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Moreover, direct visualization of treponemes would only be possible on darkfield microscopy, not on light microscopy.

F) INCORRECT:

Vaginal candidiasis is caused by Candida albicans. Even though vaginal candidiasis also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically odorless, white, and crumbly. Additional symptoms of vaginal candidiasis include intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast
questions.hint: Applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with this patient's vaginal discharge will cause a fishy odor.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal itchiness and urinary frequency for the past year. She stopped having vaginal intercourse with her husband because it became painful and occasionally resulted in vaginal spotting. Her last menstrual period was 14 months ago. She has vitiligo. Her only medication is a topical tacrolimus ointment. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple white maculae on her forearms, abdomen, and feet. Pelvic examination shows scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thinning of the vaginal mucosa leading to tissue inflammation is characteristic of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is most commonly caused by decreased estrogen levels after menopause. Signs and symptoms in addition to this patient's urogenital findings include decreased vulvovaginal secretions and sensation of vulvovaginal dryness, loss of vaginal elasticity and rugal folds, a decreased labial fat pad, vaginal discharge, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is primarily a clinical diagnosis and treatment consists of nonhormonal vaginal moisturizers and lubricants, as well as topical or systemic estrogen therapy in more severe cases.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the greater vestibular glands (Bartholin glands) may lead to blockage of the Bartholin duct, fluid buildup, and cystic dilation of the glands. Bartholin gland cysts are most commonly asymptomatic but may manifest with dyspareunia. However, these cysts are not associated with vaginal itchiness, postcoital spotting, urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, or a narrowed vaginal introitus. Moreover, Bartholin gland cysts are typically palpable at the base of the labia minora.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrophic vaginitis is caused by a decrease in estrogen levels, most commonly due to menopause. Estrogen regulates the pH of the lower genital tract by acting on vaginal and cervical epithelial cells to increase acid secretion. Atrophic vaginitis is therefore associated with an increase, not decrease, in vaginal pH (typically ≥ 5; normal vaginal pH 4–4.5).

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) (i.e., epithelial dysplasia), a precancerous lesion that is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, VIN is not typically associated with urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, or narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Instead, common examination findings include vulvar plaques, ulcers, or masses (fleshy, nodular, or warty), and lymphadenopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis) secondary to a decrease in vaginal lactobacilli colonization and a subsequent pH increase is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV may manifest with vaginal itchiness and dyspareunia. However, this infection is not associated with postcoital spotting, urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and/or narrowed vaginal introitus. Moreover, BV typically manifests with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor, which is not present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for lichen sclerosus (LS), a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by sclerosis of the vulvar dermis and most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, vulvar LS is not associated with urinary frequency and scarce pubic hair. Instead, common findings include dysuria, anal discomfort, and characteristic porcelain-white atrophic patches as well as obliteration of the labia minora and clitoris on examination. Moreover, the multiple white cutaneous spots found on examination can be attributed to her vitiligo.
Image Description:

An irregular, sclerotic white plaque with a reddened, inflammatory edge localized to the vulva and perianal region is visible. The labia minora and majora are hard to distinguish from one another because of atrophy and sclerosis; the vaginal opening is markedly narrowed.
questions.hint: Scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, a narrowed vaginal introitus, and vaginal dryness leading to dyspareunia are consistent with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text:
A 21-year-old female college student presents to university health services reporting one week of vaginal irritation and malodorous discharge. She has been sexually active with one female partner. Her last menstrual period, 2 weeks ago, was normal.
Her external genitalia are normal but show some moderate whitish discharge. Her cervix also appears to be normal, with no cervical-motion tenderness.
Vaginal pH is 4.8, and a Gram stain examination of the discharge is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is indicated for herpes simplex virus infection.

B) CORRECT:

Bacterial vaginosis (BV), the most frequent cause of acute, symptomatic vaginitis, is not uncommon among women who have sex with women. Symptoms typically include white or grey discharge and increased odor. Physical symptoms and examination findings are nonspecific, so further diagnostic testing is required when BV is suspected. Typically, this includes obtaining a vaginal pH and a wet mount for microscopic examination. In this case, a Gram stain was obtained, which is more labor-intensive but shows the same clue cells that would be seen on a wet mount. Clue cells are vaginal squamous epithelial cells with adherent gram-negative rods.

BV can be diagnosed if three of the following four findings are documented: vaginal pH >4.5; watery discharge; presence of >20% clue cells on wet mount; positive amine odor test. (The amine odor is produced after mixing 10% potassium hydroxide with a sample of vaginal discharge.)

Appropriate therapy for BV is intravaginal metronidazole for 5 days or oral metronidazole for 7 days. Single-dose oral metronidazole is another option, but it is associated with more adverse effects and a greater likelihood of treatment failure.

Key learning point: The most appropriate therapy for bacterial vaginosis is intravaginal metronidazole for 5 days or oral metronidazole for 7 days.

C) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline (or, alternatively, azithromycin) is used to treat chlamydia. However, this patient’s presentation and findings on Gram stain examination are more consistent with bacterial vaginosis; thus, treatment for these other infections is not indicated. Chlamydia and gonorrhea are uncommon in women who have sex with women, although appropriate testing and treatment should be offered if the clinical presentation is consistent with these infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline (or, alternatively, azithromycin) is used to treat chlamydia. However, this patient’s presentation and findings on Gram stain examination are more consistent with bacterial vaginosis; thus, treatment for these other infections is not indicated. Chlamydia and gonorrhea are uncommon in women who have sex with women, although appropriate testing and treatment should be offered if the clinical presentation is consistent with these infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is used to treat gonorrhea. However, this patient’s presentation and findings on Gram stain examination are more consistent with bacterial vaginosis; thus, treatment for these other infections is not indicated. Chlamydia and gonorrhea are uncommon in women who have sex with women, although appropriate testing and treatment should be offered if the clinical presentation is consistent with these infections.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes reports a 3-day history of vaginal pruritus, increased vaginal discharge, and dysuria. She has not had a urinary tract infection in the past year. She uses intravaginal estriol for atrophic vaginitis.
On examination, she has vulvar erythema and foamy, thick vaginal discharge, with a punctate-appearing cervix. She reports an increase in the amount of drainage and a change in the character of the discharge since her last sexual encounter, approximately 2 months ago.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Perform a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid
Recommend a diagnostic trial of not using the estriol cream

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms suggest infection with Trichomonas vaginalis, a sexually transmitted protozoan parasite that causes 5% to 50% of cases of acute vaginitis.

Infection with T. vaginalis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infection in the United States. Symptoms in women include vaginal discharge, pruritus, vaginal irritation, and a punctate-appearing cervix on examination (known as “strawberry cervix”). Infection with T. vaginalis is best diagnosed by culture or polymerase chain-reaction testing, but the diagnosis can be made by vaginal or cervical fluid microscopy and the presence of motile trichomonads; sensitivity of the wet mount is about 60%.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of vaginitis and foamy vaginal discharge is Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Performing a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid is not indicated because Trichomonas is a protozoan parasite and grows only in specialized media.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is not indicated because this patient has clear physical examination findings consistent with her symptoms of vaginitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring vaginal fluid pH is not specific for Trichomonas because pH is also elevated in bacterial vaginosis. That diagnosis should also be considered in this patient, but the next step in management is the same (wet mount microscopy) with either diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A diagnostic trial of not using estriol cream is not indicated, as estriol does not typically cause local inflammation.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman reports a 5-day history of vulvar pruritus. She describes having an increase in vaginal discharge but denies any odor, dysuria, or lesions. She is sexually active with male partners and has an intrauterine device in place. She does not use condoms.
On physical examination, the labia majora and minora are erythematous with excoriations. The vaginal mucosa is erythematous, with a thick white discharge. The cervix has a normal appearance without any lesions, and the strings of the intrauterine device are noted to be in the correct position.
A sample of the vaginal discharge is taken and noted to have a pH <4.5. A microscopic evaluation of the discharge is performed (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervicitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae is typically asymptomatic but can manifest with purulent or mucopurulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual bleeding caused by endocervical bleeding. On wet mount, an increased number of white cells with normal epithelial cells are present (>10 white cells per high-power field). Chlamydia trachomatis cervicitis and N. gonorrhoeae cervicitis are diagnosed by testing urine or by collecting swab specimens from the endocervix or vagina.

B) INCORRECT:

The three most common causes of vaginitis are bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required: see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table. In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichen sclerosus, a dermatologic condition often characterized by severe vulvar pruritus, occurs most commonly among prepubertal girls and perimenopausal women. On physical examination, white papules or patches are present in the vulvar area; the condition is not associated with vaginal discharge.

D) INCORRECT:

The three most common causes of vaginitis are bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required: see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table. In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Lactobacilli are the dominant bacteria in the normal vaginal flora, living at a pH of 3.8 to 4.5. The three most common causes of vaginitis — bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas — disrupt this environment. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required. See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis. The diagnosis can be confirmed by finding hyphae and spores on a wet-mount examination.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who has vaginal erythema and a thick white discharge with a pH <4.5 is vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman with obesity presents for follow-up of type 2 diabetes. She has been taking metformin and, 4 months ago, started taking dapagliflozin after a measured glycated hemoglobin level of 7.7%. Her most recent glycated hemoglobin level is 6.7%.
She reports that last week, she developed genital itching, burning, and discharge. She reports no dysuria or urinary frequency or hesitancy. A wet mount of the discharge reveals budding yeast. She is uncomfortable and asks whether she should stop the new diabetes medication.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Continue dapagliflozin, and reassure the patient that her vaginal condition will resolve as her glucose levels decline
Continue dapagliflozin, and prescribe oral fluconazole 150 mg as a single dose
Discontinue dapagliflozin, and recommend clotrimazole 2% cream vaginally for 3 days
Switch to empagliflozin, and prescribe oral fluconazole 150 mg as a single dose
Discontinue dapagliflozin, and recommend probiotics twice daily for one week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone is not sufficient in this case. Although vulvovaginal candidiasis is less common after prolonged use of SGLT-2 inhibitors, a symptomatic patient should be offered treatment. Unfortunately, there is no evidence that probiotics are helpful in treating vulvovaginal candidiasis.

B) CORRECT:

Sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin, prevent the reabsorption of glucose from the glomerular filtrate back into the blood, thereby increasing the level of glucose in the urine. In general, SGLT-2 inhibitors improve glycemic control and reduce body weight. Although these agents are generally well tolerated, treatment-related glycosuria is believed to contribute to an increased risk for genital mycotic infections, especially in women. This patient’s symptoms and wet-mount findings are classic for vulvovaginal candidiasis.

SGLT-2 inhibitor-associated vulvovaginal candidal infections are usually mild to moderate and rarely require discontinuation of the drug. In clinical trials, 10% of women taking canagliflozin reported having a yeast infection compared with about 3% of those taking placebo. Most yeast infections occurred in the first 4 months of SGLT-2 inhibitor use, responded well to conventional antifungal treatment, and did not recur. Given these data, the best course of action for this patient is to continue the dapagliflozin and start an antifungal medication, either oral or topical. Switching to empagliflozin would not be appropriate, as the increase in vulvovaginal candidiasis seems to be a class effect.

Key learning point: Patients who experience vulvovaginal candidiasis after initiating a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor are best managed by continuing the SGLT-2 inhibitor and starting antifungal treatment

C) INCORRECT:

SGLT-2 inhibitor-associated vulvovaginal candidal infections are usually mild to moderate and rarely require discontinuation of the drug. Most yeast infections occurred in the first 4 months of SGLT-2 inhibitor use, responded well to conventional antifungal treatment, and did not recur. Given these data, the best course of action for this patient is to continue the dapagliflozin and start an antifungal medication, either oral or topical.

D) INCORRECT:

Switching to empagliflozin would not be appropriate, as the increase in vulvovaginal candidiasis seems to be a class effect.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance alone is not sufficient in this case. Although vulvovaginal candidiasis is less common after prolonged use of SGLT-2 inhibitors, a symptomatic patient should be offered treatment. Unfortunately, there is no evidence that probiotics are helpful in treating vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports 3 days of malodorous, nonpainful, nonpruritic vaginal discharge. She has one new male sexual partner and uses condoms most of the time. She reports no dyspareunia. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago.
She is afebrile, her heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Her abdominal examination is unremarkable. Her genitourinary examination reveals normal external genitalia. There is a thin, gray discharge noted in the vagina. The cervix appears normal, and there is no cervical-motion tenderness.
A urine pregnancy test is negative. A sample of the vaginal discharge reveals a pH of 5.0. A wet mount of the discharge is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Miconazole is an appropriate treatment for candidiasis, which is typically characterized by thick, white vaginal discharge and hyphae that are visualized on wet-mount examination.

B) INCORRECT:

The identification and elimination of irritants would be appropriate for managing noninfectious vaginitis. This condition is often confused with Candida vaginitis because of the similar symptoms (pruritus, burning, and variable discharge). Clue cells are indicative of bacterial vaginosis and should be treated.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance would be appropriate for a patient with physiologic discharge. This patient has findings of bacterial vaginosis and would benefit from treatment.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and wet-mount examination are consistent with bacterial vaginosis. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis requires three of the following four features:

• Thin, watery vaginal discharge
• Vaginal pH >4.5
• Wet mount revealing more than 20% clue cells (vaginal squamous epithelial cells with adherent coccobacilli)
• A positive amine odor test (The amine odor is produced after mixing 10% potassium hydroxide [KOH] with a sample of vaginal discharge.)

First-line treatment consists of oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or intravaginal metronidazole 5 grams daily for 5 days. Clindamycin is an alternate treatment for bacterial vaginosis and is as effective as metronidazole at eradicating the infection.

Given that this patient is sexually active and using condoms only intermittently, she should receive counseling about the risks of unplanned pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young woman with malodorous vaginal discharge, a vaginal pH >4.5, and clue cells visible on wet mount is bacterial vaginosis, which is best treated with either metronidazole or clindamycin.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for chlamydia. Testing this patient for chlamydia would be reasonable, but most clinicians would not treat for chlamydia in this scenario without a positive test.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl with no significant medical history reports 3 days of malodorous, nonpainful, nonpruritic vaginal discharge. She has one new male sexual partner and uses condoms most of the time. She reports no dyspareunia. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago.
She is afebrile, her heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Her abdominal examination is unremarkable. Her genitourinary examination reveals normal external genitalia. There is a thin, gray discharge noted in the vagina. The cervix appears normal, and there is no cervical-motion tenderness.
A urine pregnancy test is negative. A sample of the vaginal discharge reveals a pH of 5.0. A wet mount of the discharge is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Miconazole is an appropriate treatment for candidiasis, which is typically characterized by thick, white vaginal discharge and hyphae that are visualized on wet-mount examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is used to treat chlamydia. Testing this patient for chlamydia would be reasonable, but most clinicians would not treat for chlamydia without a positive test.

C) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod is an immunomodulatory topical treatment appropriate for treating anogenital warts, not bacterial vaginosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used to treat chlamydia. Testing this patient for chlamydia would be reasonable, but most clinicians would not treat for chlamydia without a positive test.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and wet-mount examination are consistent with bacterial vaginosis. The diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis requires three of the following four features:

• Thin, watery vaginal discharge
• Vaginal pH >4.5
• Wet mount revealing more than 20% clue cells (vaginal squamous epithelial cells with adherent coccobacilli)
• A positive amine odor test (The amine odor is produced after mixing 10% potassium hydroxide [KOH] with a sample of vaginal discharge.)

First-line treatment consists of oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or intravaginal metronidazole 5 grams daily for 5 days. Clindamycin is an alternate treatment for bacterial vaginosis and is as effective as metronidazole at eradicating the infection.

Given that this patient is sexually active and using condoms only intermittently, she should receive counseling about the risks of unplanned pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adolescent with malodorous vaginal discharge, a vaginal pH >4.5, and clue cells visible on wet mount is bacterial vaginosis, which is best treated with either metronidazole or clindamycin.

questions.text:
A young woman, 18 years of age, reports a 5-day history of vulvar pruritus. She describes having an increase in vaginal discharge but denies any odor, dysuria, or lesions. She is sexually active with male partners and has an intrauterine device in place. She does not use condoms.
On physical examination, the labia majora and minora are erythematous with excoriations. The vaginal mucosa is erythematous, with a thick white discharge. The cervix has a normal appearance without any lesions, and the strings of the intrauterine device are noted to be in the correct position.
A sample of the vaginal discharge is taken and noted to have a pH <4.5. A microscopic evaluation of the discharge is performed (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lactobacilli are the dominant bacteria in the normal vaginal flora, living at a pH of 3.8 to 4.5. The three most common causes of vaginitis — bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas — disrupt this environment. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required. In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis. The diagnosis can be confirmed by finding hyphae and spores on a wet-mount examination. See "Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge" table.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a young woman who has vaginal erythema and a thick white discharge with a pH <4.5 is vulvovaginal candidiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervicitis caused by Chlamydiatrachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae is typically asymptomatic but can manifest with purulent or mucopurulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual bleeding caused by endocervical bleeding. On wet mount, an increased number of white cells with normal epithelial cells are present (>10 white cells per high-power field). Chlamydia trachomatis cervicitis and N. gonorrhoeae cervicitis are diagnosed by testing urine or by collecting swab specimens from the endocervix or vagina.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichen sclerosus is a dermatologic condition often characterized by severe vulvar pruritus. It occurs most commonly among prepubertal girls and perimenopausal women. On physical examination, white papules or patches are present in the vulvar area; the condition is not associated with vaginal discharge.

D) INCORRECT:

The three most common causes of vaginitis — bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas — can be distinguished with a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation. See "Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge" table.

E) INCORRECT:

The three most common causes of vaginitis — bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas — can be distinguished with a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation. See "Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge" table.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old previously healthy woman presents with “smelly” vaginal discharge for the past 5 days. She reports no fever, abdominal pain, pruritus, dysuria, hematuria, or history of any similar problem. She takes no medications. Her menstrual periods are regular every 28 days; the most recent one began 7 days ago. She is sexually active with women.
Her vital signs are stable, she appears well, and her abdominal examination is benign. Genitourinary examination identifies no vulvar lesions, erythema, or edema. Speculum examination reveals a white, homogeneous, watery discharge with a fishy odor that smoothly coats the vaginal walls. A sample of the discharge is collected for further examination. There is no cervical motion or adnexal tenderness.
Which of the following additional findings, if present on further examination of the vaginal discharge, would most support the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: The pH of the discharge is 4.0
Large numbers of neutrophils are present
30% of visualized epithelial cells have attached coccobacilli
Oval organisms with smaller oval outgrowths are present
Spinning, pear-shaped organisms with flagella are present

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal vaginal pH ranges from 4 to 4.5, and physiological vaginal discharge is white or clear. However, normal discharge is not malodorous. This patient presents with vaginal discharge that has a fishy odor; the most likely cause is an infection that increases vaginal pH. Furthermore, physiological discharge is typically more pronounced when estrogen levels are higher, and this patient presents with discharge during the first week of her menstrual cycle, in which estrogen levels are low.

Vulvovaginal candidiasis can also result in white discharge and normal vaginal pH. However, discharge is typically clumpy rather than thin. Moreover, in patients with this condition, the amine test is negative, and features of inflammation (erythema, edema, excoriations, pruritus) are often present.

B) INCORRECT:

Abundant neutrophils are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which causes vaginitis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection that can be acquired from partners of any gender and may manifest with a foul-smelling odor. However, features of inflammation (erythema, pruritus, dysuria, dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding) are usually expected, and discharge is typically frothy and yellow-green.

C) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis (BV), which manifests with a thin, homogeneous, white, gray, yellow, or milky discharge with a fishy odor. Symptoms are usually more prominent after sexual activity or during menses. BV may be diagnosed using Amsel criteria, which involves pH testing and microscopy of a swab collected by the patient or clinician. Three of the four following Amsel criteria must be met:

•Thin, homogeneous gray, white, or yellow discharge that adheres to the vaginal walls
•pH of the discharge >4.5
•Positive amine test (fishy odor when a drop of KOH is added to the sample)
•≥20% clue cells on saline wet mount

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with attached coccobacilli, and their presence on wet mount is the most specific criterion for BV. Gram staining can also be used for diagnosis, but the process is more complex.

BV occurs when there are lower concentrations of the usually predominant vaginal species, Lactobacillus, which leads to an overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobic organisms. The exact trigger for this change is unknown. BV is more common in individuals who are sexually active (with partners of any gender), but it is not a sexually transmitted infection. Because BV is not an inflammatory process, there are typically no signs of inflammation (e.g., vulvar erythema, vulvar edema, or large numbers of neutrophils), and the condition is often asymptomatic.

The standard treatment for BV is oral or vaginal administration of metronidazole or clindamycin. Treatment failure and recurrence rates are high. Complications include an increased risk for STIs and other infections, as well as pregnancy complications. Unlike with STIs, sexual partners of patients with BV do not require treatment. See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

Key learning point: Bacterial vaginosis may be diagnosed clinically if at least 3 of the following 4 criteria are met: (1) homogeneous, thin, gray, white, or yellow discharge; (2) pH of the discharge >4.5; (3) fishy odor when KOH is added to the sample of discharge; (4) ≥20% clue cells on saline wet mount.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with vulvovaginal candidiasis, saline microscopy typically shows hyphae, budding yeast (oval organisms with smaller oval outgrowths), or pseudohyphae.
