Although vulvovaginal candidiasis can manifest with white discharge, it is typically clumpy. Moreover, in patients with this condition, amine test is negative, and features of inflammation (erythema, edema, excoriations, pruritus) are often present.

E) INCORRECT:

Mobile, pear-shaped organisms with flagella (Trichomonas vaginalis) on saline microscopy are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which causes vaginitis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection that can be acquired from partners of any gender and may manifest with a foul-smelling odor. However, features of inflammation (erythema, pruritus, dysuria, dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding) are usually present, and discharge is typically frothy and yellow-green.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl with autism spectrum disorder is brought to the clinic by her mother for vaginal discomfort. The girl is nonverbal, but the mother has noticed her “itching her private areas a lot” during the past few days. The mother states that her daughter does not have great personal hygiene but enjoys taking bubble baths every night. She has not had any appetite changes, fevers, vomiting, or diarrhea. She takes no medications and has not yet reached menarche. She lives with her mother, father, brother, and sister, and she attends a school for children with autism.
Her vital signs are normal, and her BMI is at the 95th percentile. She appears well, and an abdominal examination is normal. Sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) is 3 for both breast development and pubic hair. An external genitourinary examination is very limited due to the patient’s discomfort but shows some vulvar erythema, edema, and excoriations, as well as some vaginal discharge. A brief visual inspection of the anus shows mild erythema. Samples of the vaginal discharge are collected and sent out for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT). The patient is only able to produce a very small urine sample, so urinalysis is deferred in order to culture the sample. A urine pregnancy test is negative.
Wet mount microscopy of the vaginal discharge is shown.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and doxycycline are used to treat gonorrhea and chlamydia respectively, and these STIs frequently occur together. Both may be asymptomatic or can manifest with mucopurulent vaginal discharge, dysuria, or pruritis. Diagnosis of these infections is confirmed with NAAT of urine, vaginal, or cervical specimens. Microscopy is not used for diagnosing either STI.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral or topical azoles, such as fluconazole, are used to treat vulvovaginal candidiasis, which manifests with features of vulvar inflammation (erythema, edema, excoriations, pruritus). This condition also manifests with vaginal discharge, but it is typically white, odorless, and clumpy. Other findings of vulvovaginal candidiasis include a normal pH of 4 to 4.5. Microscopy shows hyphae, pseudohyphae, or budding yeast, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of fungus germination (KOH preparation, 600x)

Mother cells (blastospores; green overlay) produce a hyphal outgrowth of germ tubes (budding; dashed red outline).

Budding is suggestive of active candida infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonspecific vulvovaginitis is common in premenarchal children, and risk factors include poor hygiene, retained foreign bodies (e.g., toilet paper), irritating chemicals (e.g., bubble baths), obesity, and tight-fitting pants. This condition commonly manifests with vaginal discharge, pruritus, erythema, and/or odor. Although there is no diagnostic test for nonspecific vulvovaginitis, this patient presents with some features of the condition. Treatment includes taking daily baths without soap in the vaginal area, avoiding tight or wet pants, and receiving assistance with toileting as needed. Baking soda baths are not helpful in treating an infectious cause of vaginitis, and this patient presents with features of an infection.

D) CORRECT:

The wet mount shows many Trichomonas vaginalis parasites, the organisms responsible for trichomoniasis. Because trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI), in addition to providing treatment, a sexual abuse workup and investigation are required in pediatric patients. Suspected abuse should be reported to child protective services, and testing for other STIs, including HIV, syphilis, chlamydia, and gonorrhea should be performed.

Oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days is the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis, which typically manifests with malodorous yellow-green frothy vaginal discharge, vaginal pruritus, burning or irritation, and/or vulvar erythema or edema. Sexual partners should also be treated. Other findings include dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and dysuria. However, infection can be asymptomatic. A speculum examination should be performed in sexually active adults but is not appropriate in children.

The preferred diagnostic test for trichomoniasis is NAAT of vaginal, cervical, or urine specimens; however, results take several days. In-office diagnosis with pH testing and microscopy is considered when NAAT is not available, but it is less sensitive. Trichomoniasis is characterized by a pH >4.5 and wet mount microscopy showing flagellated, pear-shaped trichomonads with jerky or spinning movements and abundant neutrophils.

Key learning point: Trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection, manifests with vulvovaginal pruritus and erythema, is diagnosed by visualization of motile trichomonads, and is treated with metronidazole.

E) INCORRECT:

Mebendazole, albendazole, and pyrantel pamoate are treatment options for enterobiasis. This condition can lead to vulvovaginitis, especially in children, but typically causes perianal pruritus rather than vaginal pruritus. Pinworms can be observed with the naked eye or seen on microscopy, which also shows bean-shaped eggs.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a specimen prepared by applying cellulose tape to the anal region of a patient (very high magnification)

Eight transparent, elongated oval eggs, which are flattened asymmetrically on one side can be seen.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student presents with a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She also noticed white vaginal discharge despite cleaning her genital area daily using a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is worried that she might have contracted a sexually transmitted disease. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient swims for the college swimming team. She had an intrauterine device implanted 3 months ago. Speculum examination shows an erythematous vagina covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4 and the microscopic image of a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.2%. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. Over the past 2 weeks, she has felt nauseous in the morning. She has also had vulvar itching and pain when urinating that started 5 days ago. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of macrosomia from gestational diabetes. Her gestational diabetes resolved after the child was born. She appears well. Ultrasound confirms fetal heart tones and an intrauterine pregnancy. Speculum examination shows a whitish chunky discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.2. A wet mount is performed and microscopic examination is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is an antibiotic used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis, but it is not appropriate for vulvovaginal candidiasis. Metronidazole should also be used with caution in the first trimester of pregnancy. Bacterial vaginosis is the most common vaginal infection in women and usually manifests with gray discharge with a fishy odor and is typically not associated with pruritus. Trichomoniasis usually manifests with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green, purulent discharge, pruritus, and dysuria. Wet mount in trichomoniasis shows protozoa with multiple flagella.

B) INCORRECT:

Treatment with probiotics such as live lactobacilli (either oral or intravaginal) have not been shown to be effective in the treatment or prevention of vaginal yeast infections. Although it is common belief that ingestion or vaginal administration of live lactobacilli (e.g., in yogurt) can restore damaged vaginal flora and prevent vulvovaginal candidiasis, there is no evidence that women with recurrent vaginal yeast infection have a deficiency in lactobacilli.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole is an azole antifungal agent primarily used for the treatment of candidiasis. However, systemic azoles are typically avoided in pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, due to the increased risk of miscarriage and possible birth defects.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravaginal clindamycin is a treatment option for bacterial vaginosis, but it is not appropriate for vulvovaginal candidiasis. Bacterial vaginosis is the most common vaginal infection in women and usually manifests with gray discharge with a fishy odor and is typically not associated with pruritus.

E) CORRECT:

Intravaginal clotrimazole is a topical antifungal agent and the first-line treatment for vulvovaginal candidiasis in pregnancy. Treatment primarily aims at symptom relief, as vulvovaginal candidiasis is not associated with adverse outcomes in pregnancy. While oral azoles are commonly used in uncomplicated infections, they are typically avoided during pregnancy, particularly during the first trimester. Complications associated with the use of oral azoles during pregnancy include miscarriage and birth defects such as abnormalities of the bones and heart. A nystatin pessary is another first-line treatment for candidal vulvovaginitis.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.
questions.hint: The patient's presentation combined with the pseudohyphae and hyphae with budding yeast on wet mount indicate vulvovaginal candidiasis. In determining the most appropriate pharmacologic agent, the patient's pregnancy has to be taken into account.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the office for a well-child examination. Her mother says she has been having trouble sleeping for 3 weeks because of pruritus in her genital area. The girl has otherwise been feeling well. She is at the 45th percentile for height and 51st percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and perianal region. There is no vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae on a potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount of a perineal or vaginal swab is diagnostic of vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC). VVC may occur in pediatric patients, but it occurs more often in children who are still in diapers (candidal diaper dermatitis), which is not the case with this patient. VVC is characterized by white discharge and erythema of the intertriginous folds with “satellite” papules, neither of which are seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Perianal cellophane-tape examination (i.e., a tape test) is the diagnostic test for Enterobius vermicularis infection. At night, female worms migrate from the colon to the anal opening, where they deposit eggs, which cause perianal and vulvar irritation and pruritus. The test is conducted by applying a transparent piece of cellophane tape to the anal opening early in the morning; any ova of Enterobius vermicularis will then stick to the tape. By pressing the sticky side of the tape against a slide, anything picked up by the tape can be examined for the presence of eggs. If the tape test confirms pinworm infection, treatment of the entire household with albendazole or mebendazole is indicated to prevent reinfection.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the colon

A worm is visible in the colon (green overlay). The surrounding mucosa's surface and vascular pattern appear normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Wet mount microscopy is used to diagnose suspected trichomoniasis or bacterial vaginosis. While a burning sensation in the vulvovaginal area is a typical feature of trichomoniasis, a foul-smelling, yellow-green discharge is usually present as well. Bacterial vaginosis does not commonly cause vulvovaginal pruritus and instead presents with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. The absence of vaginal discharge in this patient makes these infections unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Sexual abuse, and therefore STDs, are a concern in minors presenting with vulvovaginitis. However, in this patient, the absence of genital lesions or evidence of trauma make sexual abuse unlikely. Moreover, infections with Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea are most often asymptomatic or manifest with symptoms of cervicitis (e.g., vaginal discharge or pain, bleeding on manipulation), urethritis (e.g., urethral discharge, dysuria, and urinary frequency), or pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., fever, abdominal/pelvic pain). Nocturnal vulvar pruritus and erythema of the vulva and perianal region would not be expected.
Image Description:

Purulent discharge can be seen on this patient's vulva on external genital examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Stool microscopy can be used to diagnose gastrointestinal infections with protozoans (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica) or helminths (e.g., roundworms, tapeworms, and hookworms). In helminth infection, worm eggs (ova) can be detected in the stool. Enterobiasis, however, cannot be diagnosed reliably with stool microscopy because the ova of Enterobius vermicularis are almost never shed in feces. Instead, the gravid female worms migrate to the anal opening at night and deposit the ova there.
questions.hint: Anogenital pruritus (especially at night) in a toddler or preschooler is a classic symptom of enterobiasis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the office because of yellow vaginal discharge, itching, and pain with urination for the past 6 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vagina and cervix with well-defined punctate hemorrhages and foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.8. Bimanual examination is unremarkable. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common cause of sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. Infection with chlamydia is often asymptomatic. If symptoms appear, they typically include (muco)purulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding. Furthermore, physical examination of the cervix often causes bleeding, whereas the bimanual examination of this patient was unremarkable.

B) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative diplococci indicate infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonorrhea). The disease is transmitted sexually and is usually asymptomatic in women. If symptoms arise, they typically include purulent, creamy vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding but no erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface; these cells are characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. The vaginal discharge in bacterial vaginosis also has pH > 4.5. Unlike in this patient, bacterial vaginosis usually manifests without vulvovaginal erythema and the discharge is white or grey-colored and has a fishy odor.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)

Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.

The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae are loosely filamentous forms of fungi assumed by many yeasts, particularly Candida albicans, during growth. They are commonly seen on wet mounts of patients with vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis), which are associated with odorless, white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge that may resemble cottage cheese. Pregnancy, antibiotic use, and immunosuppression are predisposing factors for vaginal thrush. Even though this patient had a course of amoxicillin, her discharge is foul-smelling and yellow-green, making a candidal infection very unlikely. Also, vaginal pH is typically normal (4–4.5) in vulvovaginal candidiasis.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

E) CORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile protozoan with multiple flagella. Patients typically have foul-smelling, frothy, purulent vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Transmission of this disease occurs through unprotected sex. Most patients remain asymptomatic. Treatment consists of oral metronidazole or tinidazole for the patient and sexual partner(s).

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.
questions.hint: Vaginal and cervical erythema with punctate hemorrhages (strawberry cervix) along with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with an elevated pH value is consistent with trichomoniasis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes reports a 3-day history of vaginal pruritus, increased vaginal discharge, and dysuria. She has not had a urinary tract infection in the past year. She uses intravaginal estriol for atrophic vaginitis. On examination, she has vulvar erythema and foamy, thick vaginal discharge, with a punctate-appearing cervix. She reports an increase in the amount of drainage and a change in the character of the discharge since her last sexual encounter, approximately 2 months ago. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Perform a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid
Recommend a diagnostic trial of not using the estriol cream

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms suggest infection with Trichomonas vaginalis, a sexually transmitted protozoan parasite that causes 5% to 50% of cases of acute vaginitis.

Infection with T. vaginalis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infection in the United States. Symptoms in women include vaginal discharge, pruritus, vaginal irritation, and a punctate-appearing cervix on examination (known as “strawberry cervix”). Infection with T. vaginalis is best diagnosed by culture or polymerase chain-reaction testing, but the diagnosis can be made by vaginal or cervical fluid microscopy and the presence of motile trichomonads; sensitivity of the wet mount is about 60%.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of vaginitis and foamy vaginal discharge is Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Performing a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid is not indicated because Trichomonas is a protozoan parasite and grows only in specialized media.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is not indicated because this patient has clear physical examination findings consistent with her symptoms of vaginitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring vaginal fluid pH is not specific for Trichomonas because pH is also elevated in bacterial vaginosis. That diagnosis should also be considered in this patient, but the next step in management is the same (wet mount microscopy) with either diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

A diagnostic trial of not using estriol cream is not indicated, as estriol does not typically cause local inflammation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman reports a 5-day history of vulvar pruritus. She describes having an increase in vaginal discharge but denies any odor, dysuria, or lesions. She is sexually active with male partners and has an intrauterine device in place. She does not use condoms. On physical examination, the labia majora and minora are erythematous with excoriations. The vaginal mucosa is erythematous, with a thick white discharge. The cervix has a normal appearance without any lesions, and the strings of the intrauterine device are noted to be in the correct position. A sample of the vaginal discharge is taken and noted to have a pH <4.5. A microscopic evaluation of the discharge is performed (figure). Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cervicitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae is typically asymptomatic but can manifest with purulent or mucopurulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual bleeding caused by endocervical bleeding. On wet mount, an increased number of white cells with normal epithelial cells are present (>10 white cells per high-power field). Chlamydia trachomatis cervicitis and N. gonorrhoeae cervicitis are diagnosed by testing urine or by collecting swab specimens from the endocervix or vagina.

B) INCORRECT:

The three most common causes of vaginitis are bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required: see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table. In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichen sclerosus, a dermatologic condition often characterized by severe vulvar pruritus, occurs most commonly among prepubertal girls and perimenopausal women. On physical examination, white papules or patches are present in the vulvar area; the condition is not associated with vaginal discharge.

D) INCORRECT:

The three most common causes of vaginitis are bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required: see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table. In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis.

E) CORRECT:

Lactobacilli are the dominant bacteria in the normal vaginal flora, living at a pH of 3.8 to 4.5. The three most common causes of vaginitis — bacterial vaginosis, Candida, and Trichomonas — disrupt this environment. To distinguish among these causes, a directed history, pelvic examination, and microscopic evaluation are required. See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

In this case, the appearance and pH of the discharge (thick and white; <4.5), coupled with the vaginal erythema, suggest vulvovaginal candidiasis. The diagnosis can be confirmed by finding hyphae and spores on a wet-mount examination.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who has vaginal erythema and a thick white discharge with a pH <4.5 is vulvovaginal candidiasis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-day history of vaginal discharge. She has no pain or pruritus. Menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. Temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows malodorous, gray vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.0. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea. Gonorrhea also manifests with vaginal discharge, but the discharge is typically odorless, purulent, and creamy. The patient is also lacking symptoms of dysuria, dyspareunia, and intermenstrual bleeding, which are typical accompanying features.

B) CORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is an anaerobic bacterium that causes bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with gray, malodorous vaginal discharge. There are two characteristic diagnostic findings of BV: clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria) seen on a wet mount preparation and a positive amine test (sometimes referred to as the “whiff test”). The amine test consists of applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with vaginal discharge and is positive if this causes a fishy or amine odor.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in the US and a common cause of female infertility. C. trachomatis infection is often asymptomatic, but if discharge occurs, it is usually odorless and purulent. Clue cells are not associated with C. trachomatis, and instead it is usually diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification tests.

D) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Even though C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically odorless, white, and crumbly, and the vaginal pH would be normal (< 4.5). Additional symptoms of infection with C. albicans include intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

E) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite and one of the etiologic agents of vulvovaginitis. Although T. vaginalis would cause malodorous vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5, the discharge is usually yellow-green and frothy. Additionally, vulvovaginitis due to T. vaginalis manifests with pruritus, and the microscopic examination of the discharge would instead show flagellated protozoa.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of trichomonas vaginalis trophozoites (Giemsa stain; high magnification)

The protozoan appears oval-shaped with flagella (examples indicated by arrowheads) and a nucleus (green overlay) located at the anterior end.
questions.hint: Malodorous, gray vaginal discharge, an increased vaginal pH, and clue cells on microscopy are consistent with bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office because of vaginal discharge for the past 3 days. She has no dysuria, dyspareunia, pruritus, or burning. The patient is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She often douches after sexual intercourse. Pelvic examination shows thin and off-white vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.1. Wet mount examination shows that a quarter of vaginal epithelial cells are covered with small coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Treat the patient with ceftriaxone and doxycycline
Treat the patient and partners with metronidazole
Treat the patient and partners with ceftriaxone and doxycycline
Provide reassurance and schedule follow-up in one week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and in patients with coinfection. Gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, vaginal pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia are common, together with a purulent, creamy discharge. However, this patient has no symptoms aside from a thin, off-white discharge. Additionally, if gonorrhea were present, treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days because of potentially severe complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, urethritis, and/or infertility. As doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy, a pregnancy test should be obtained before initiation of pharmacotherapy as this patient uses condoms inconsistently.

B) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is indicated for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. However, as bacterial vaginosis is not a sexually transmitted infection, partner treatment is not necessary. Antibiotic treatment for both the patient and the partner is indicated in patients with infectious vulvovaginitis caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, such as trichomoniasis, which would manifest with a frothy, foul-smelling discharge with a pH ≥ 4.5 and flagellated protozoa on a wet mount.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and in patients with coinfection. Treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days because of potentially severe complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, urethritis, and/or infertility. Gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, vaginal pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia are common, together with a purulent, creamy discharge. However, this patient has no symptoms aside from a thin, off-white discharge. As doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy, a pregnancy test should be obtained before initiation of pharmacotherapy as this patient uses condoms inconsistently.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance would be adequate if the patient did not have vaginal discharge and if bacterial vaginosis had been incidentally diagnosed during a routine check-up. Symptomatic bacterial vaginosis, however, does require treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Metronidazole is prescribed for anaerobic infections with pathogens such as Gardnerella vaginalis, the cause of bacterial vaginosis. Although sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis, this condition is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an imbalance of the vaginal flora resulting in overgrowth of Gardnerella bacteria (and a relative lack of the normally dominant lactobacilli). Another risk factor for this imbalance is vaginal douching, which this woman reports she does regularly. Bacterial vaginosis is commonly asymptomatic, but when symptomatic, individuals should receive treatment with either oral or topical metronidazole. The CDC recommends that women who are being treated for bacterial vaginosis refrain from sexual activity or use condoms consistently and correctly as well as avoid douching, as it increases the risk of relapse.

Key learning point: Bacterial vaginosis is treated with metronidazole, and partner treatment is not necessary because it is not a sexually transmitted infection.
Image Description:

Speculum view of the cervix with thin gray and milky discharge
questions.hint: Based on the color and pH value of the vaginal discharge and the wet mount showing clue cells, this patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with a 5-month history of painful sexual intercourse. She also reports vaginal pruritus and occasional spotting. She has no pain with urination. She had two urinary tract infections over the past 3 years that resolved with oral antibiotic therapy. Her last menstrual period was 8 months ago. She is sexually active with her husband and has two children. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows decreasing labial fat pad, receding pubic hair, and clear vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal drug recommended for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Although this infection may manifest with pruritus and an odorless vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually white and curd-like (“cottage cheese” appearance). Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis would also cause dysuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is a second-line antifungal drug recommended for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis. Although this infection may manifest with pruritus and an odorless vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually white and curd-like (“cottage cheese” appearance). Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis would also cause dysuria.

C) CORRECT:

Topical estrogen creams effectively alleviate symptoms of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is thought to be caused by low estrogen levels after menopause. Genitourinary syndrome of menopause can also occur postpartum or due to breastfeeding. Moisturizers and vaginal lubricants are an alternative for mild cases and can also be used as an adjunct to hormone treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is recommended as the first-line treatment for Gardnerella vaginalis and Trichomonas vaginalis infections. Although both infections may manifest with vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually foul-smelling and not clear. These infections would also not explain a decreasing labial fat pad or receding pubic hair.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used for the treatment of lichen planus. Although genital lichen planus may also cause dyspareunia and mostly affects women over 50 years of age, it is frequently accompanied by several symptoms such as vulvar pain, pruritus, and burning. Moreover, it is commonly associated with cutaneous or oral lichen planus.
questions.hint: Receding pubic hair and decreasing labial fat pads are typical symptoms for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with a four-day history of vaginal discharge and itching. She reports the discharge is frothy, yellow-green, and malodorous, worsening after sexual intercourse. She also has mild dysuria and a burning sensation around her vulva. She denies recent antibiotic use or history of similar episodes. She admits to having multiple male sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. On pelvic examination, the vaginal mucosa is diffusely erythematous with scattered punctate hemorrhages on the cervix (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Vaginal fluid




 pH
5.8
3.8 - 4.5



Microscopic examination of vaginal secretion: Motile organisms
Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vulvovaginal candidiasis, which is typically caused by Candida albicans, manifests with itching and a thick, white, 'cottage cheese-like' discharge. The normal acidic vaginal pH (3.8–4.5) is maintained, unlike the elevated pH of 5.8 here. Microscopy reveals yeast forms, not motile organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

An overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis is responsible for bacterial vaginosis, which is associated with a pH above 4.5 and a fishy odor, but the discharge is typically thin, white, and homogenous, not frothy and yellow-green. It usually lacks significant vulvar irritation, dysuria, or punctate cervical hemorrhages. Clue cells, not motile organisms, are seen on microscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal cervicitis can manifest with purulent discharge and cervical erythema but does not cause vaginal inflammation or a frothy discharge. Moreover, Neisseria gonorrhoeae are non-motile gram-negative diplococci, and punctate cervical hemorrhages are not typical of gonococcal cervicitis.

D) CORRECT:

Trichomoniasis, which manifests with frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge, malodor, vulvar irritation, and dysuria, is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, often transmitted through sexual contact. The elevated vaginal pH of 5.8 supports the diagnosis, as this protozoan thrives in less acidic environments. Additionally, punctate cervical hemorrhages, known as 'strawberry cervix,' are characteristic of this infection, resulting from localized inflammation induced by the organism. Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying motile flagellated organisms on a saline wet mount or through nucleic acid amplification tests (see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table).

Key learning point: Trichomoniasis is characterized by frothy yellow-green discharge, a strawberry cervix, and the presence of flagellated protozoa on wet preparation.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with intense vulvar itching and irritation for three days. Symptoms worsened after a recent course of antibiotics. She denies any fishy odor. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with consistent condom use. Examination shows an erythematous vulva and thick, white, odorless, clumpy discharge that clings to the vaginal walls. Vaginal pH is 4.0, and a whiff test produces no notable odor. Microscopic assessment of the discharge reveals no motile trophozoites or clue cells.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D–K can cause cervicitis, which manifests with mucopurulent or bloody cervical discharge. Vulval or vaginal inflammation are absent with chlamydia infections. The intense vulvar erythema, itching, and thick, white, clumpy discharge indicate a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Bacterial vaginosis typically presents with a thin, grayish discharge, a fishy odor, and an elevated vaginal pH above 4.5. The patient’s thick, white, clumpy discharge, normal vaginal pH of 4.0, and absence of a fishy odor do not align with bacterial vaginosis. The lack of clue cells on microscopy further argues against this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trichomoniasis usually presents with a frothy, yellow-green discharge, a fishy odor, and an elevated vaginal pH above 4.5. The normal vaginal pH of 4.0, absence of a foul odor, and lack of motile trophozoites on microscopy do not support trichomoniasis, despite the vulvar irritation.

D) CORRECT:

Vulvovaginal candidiasis manifests with intense vulvar itching and a thick, white, clumpy vaginal discharge resembling cottage cheese. The normal vaginal pH of 4.0 supports this diagnosis, as Candida species do not alter the acidic environment. The absence of a fishy odor and the recent antibiotic use, which disrupts normal vaginal flora, further suggest Candida overgrowth. Microscopic examination with a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation may reveal budding yeast or pseudohyphae (see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge”).

Key learning point: Vulvovaginal candidiasis is characterized by severe itching, thick white curdy discharge, and pseudohyphae on KOH preparation, with a normal vaginal pH and negative whiff test.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a week of vaginal discharge and a mild, unpleasant odor. She has no significant dysuria or pelvic pain. On speculum examination, the discharge is thin, grayish, and uniformly coats the vaginal walls with a slight fishy smell. The vaginal pH is 5.0 (see report).
Microscopy of vaginal discharge: Epithelial cells with numerous dotted surface irregularities
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bacterial vaginosis results from the replacement of normal lactobacilli with anaerobic bacteria and is associated with an elevated vaginal pH (greater than 4.5). This condition manifests with a thin, grayish vaginal discharge that uniformly coats the vaginal walls and emits a fishy odor that intensifies upon application of potassium hydroxide (positive whiff test) due to the production of volatile amines by anaerobic bacteria. Clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells with a stippled appearance due to bacterial adherence, are characteristic findings on microscopy (see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table).

Key learning point: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a grayish-white discharge, high vaginal pH, presence of clue cells, and a fishy odor.

B) INCORRECT:

Trichomoniasis typically presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge and symptoms like vulvar irritation or dysuria, which are absent here. Microscopy reveals motile, flagellated protozoa, not epithelial cells with dotted surface irregularities.

C) INCORRECT:

Chlamydial cervicitis usually presents with mucopurulent cervical discharge, not a thin, grayish discharge with a fishy odor. The vaginal pH typically remains normal, unlike the elevated pH observed here. The presence of clue cells suggests a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Candidiasis is characterized by thick, white, odorless curd-like discharge and marked pruritus, unlike the thin, gray, malodorous discharge described. The vaginal pH in candidiasis remains acidic, whereas it is elevated here. Microscopy typically shows budding yeast or pseudohyphae, not the dotted surface irregularities seen.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to a foul-smelling, yellowish vaginal discharge for two weeks. She has mild itching but no significant pain or fever. There is no use of new bathing products or bubble baths, and no known history of trauma or abuse. Physical examination shows localized erythema around the vaginal introitus without notable external lesions.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Candidal vulvovaginitis typically presents in postpubertal females with intense pruritus and a thick, white, cottage cheese–like discharge. In prepubertal girls, the estrogen-deficient vaginal epithelium does not favor candida overgrowth, making this condition uncommon in this age group.

B) INCORRECT:

Pinworm infection, caused by Enterobius vermicularis, commonly presents with perianal itching, especially at night. While pinworms can migrate to the vaginal area, they usually cause mild irritation without a foul-smelling, yellowish discharge. The absence of perianal pruritus or nocturnal discomfort further reduces the likelihood of pinworm infection.

C) CORRECT:

In pediatric patients, a retained vaginal foreign body often manifests with a foul-smelling yellowish discharge and minimal pain, accompanied by localized inflammation. The child's age and symptoms suggest self-insertion during exploratory behavior. The discharge's odor results from bacterial colonization of the retained object. The absence of systemic signs indicates a localized inflammatory reaction. These features help differentiate a foreign body from other causes of vaginal discharge in children, guiding appropriate evaluation and management.

Key learning point: In prepubertal children with vaginal discharge and itching, a foreign body is a common cause and should be considered in the differential diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Sexual abuse may present with genital symptoms, but typically includes signs of trauma or behavioral changes. The absence of significant pain, external injuries, or systemic symptoms, along with a lack of trauma indicators, reduces the likelihood of sexual abuse in this patient.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a week of malodorous, frothy, yellowish vaginal discharge and intense vulvar itching. She is sexually active with multiple partners and denies abdominal pain or recent antibiotic use. She has no significant past medical history and is not currently pregnant. Her vital signs are normal. Examination reveals a strawberry cervix (see report).
Wet mount of vaginal fluid: Motile, pear-shaped organisms
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

choices.text: 500 mg oral metronidazole twice daily 7 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical clindamycin is used for bacterial vaginosis, not trichomoniasis. Bacterial vaginosis manifests with malodorous grey-white vaginal discharge, but does not cause cervical inflammation or vulvar itching and is associated with clue cells on a wet mount, not motile organisms. Trichomoniasis requires systemic treatment to ensure eradication.

B) INCORRECT:

A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone is used to treat uncomplicated cervicitis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which appear as non-motile, intracellular, gram-negative diplococci. Gonococcal cervicitis can cause purulent discharge and cervical inflammation, but does not typically cause vulvar pruritus. Ceftriaxone is ineffective against trichomoniasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal used for vulvovaginal candidiasis, which is characterized by thick, white, odorless discharge and yeast forms (e.g., pseudohyphae) on a KOH mount of vaginal fluid. The presence of a strawberry cervix and motile protozoa indicates trichomoniasis, which is unresponsive to antifungals.

D) CORRECT:

Trichomoniasis manifests with malodorous, frothy, yellowish discharge, vulvar itching, and a 'strawberry cervix' due to punctate hemorrhages. Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying motile, pear-shaped protozoa on a wet mount. Metronidazole, given 500 mg PO twice daily for 7 days, is the first-line treatment. A single PO 2 g dose of tinidazole is an alternative in HIV-negative nonpregnant patients. Topical metronidazole is used to treat bacterial vaginosis, but systemic treatment is required for patients with trichomoniasis. Concurrent treatment of sexual partners is essential to prevent reinfection.

Key learning point: Oral metronidazole is the first-line treatment for Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman at 19 weeks' gestation presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of intense vulvar itching and thick, white discharge. She denies fever or abdominal pain. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Examination reveals vulvar erythema and white plaques adherent to the vaginal walls (see report).
Vaginal fluid KOH preparation: Budding yeasts and pseudohyphae
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is an antibiotic that is safe during pregnancy but it is ineffective against candidiasis. It is used to treat chlamydial cervicitis, which manifests with mucopurulent or bloody cervical discharge. Vulval or vaginal inflammation are absent with Chlamydia infections.

B) CORRECT:

Vulvovaginal candidiasis is confirmed by vulvar erythema, thick white discharge, and microscopy showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae. This condition is treated with azole antifugals. Oral azoles (e.g., fluconazole) can be used to treat nonpregnant individuals but are not recommended for use in pregnant patients because of a possible association with spontaneous abortions and fetal malformations. In pregnant patients, intravaginal azoles (e.g., clotrimazole, miconazole, terconazole) are preferred due to minimal systemic absorption, reducing fetal exposure and teratogenic risk. A 7-day course of intravaginal clotrimazole ensures effective local antifungal activity to clear the infection (see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table).

Key learning point: Vulvovaginal candidiasis, characterized by white discharge and pseudohyphae, is treated with azole antifungals.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravaginal metronidazole treats anaerobic bacterial infections like bacterial vaginosis and protozoal infections like trichomoniasis. The presence of budding yeasts and pseudohyphae indicates a fungal infection, specifically Candida species, which requires antifungals targeting the fungal cell wall or membrane. Metronidazole is ineffective against fungi.

D) INCORRECT:

A single dose of fluconazole is effective for vulvovaginal candidiasis in nonpregnant individuals due to convenient oral dosing. However, in early pregnancy, systemic azole antifungals like fluconazole are associated with congenital anomalies, making them unsuitable.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with a three-day history of foul-smelling vaginal discharge and pain during sexual intercourse. Pelvic examination shows vaginal erythema, mild tenderness, and cervical petechiae. Treatment for the patient's condition is initiated.
Which of the following is the most effective measure to prevent recurrence of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection that manifests with malodorous vaginal discharge, a strawberry cervix, and features of vulvovaginal inflammation (e.g., dyspareunia). Oral metronidazole is the treatment of choice. Concurrent treatment of sexual partners is crucial to prevent reinfection and transmission, as asymptomatic carriage is common.

Key learning point: In cases of trichomoniasis, it is crucial to treat both the patient and their sexual partner(s) with metronidazole to prevent reinfection and further transmission.

B) INCORRECT:

Although elevated vaginal pH and low levels of vaginal lactobacilli are associated with an increased risk of trichomoniasis, there is no clear evidence that vaginal probiotics can prevent its recurrence. A measure that addresses asymptomatic carriage and sexual transmission would be more effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Optimizing glycemic control prevents vulvovaginal candidiasis but is not the most effective measure to prevent trichomoniasis. Vulvovaginal candidiasis is associated with features of vaginal inflammation but causes an odorless vaginal discharge and does not cause cervical inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Regular vaginal douching increases the risk of infectious vulvovaginitis, especially bacterial vaginosis. Douching disrupts normal vaginal flora, particularly lactobacilli, which maintain an acidic pH and inhibit pathogenic overgrowth.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of a foul-smelling, thin, greyish discharge that becomes more noticeable after sexual intercourse. She reports no itching or significant discomfort. Vital signs are normal. Pelvic examination shows no vulvovaginal erythema or lesions. A whiff test is positive, and the vaginal pH is 5.3.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is effective against intracellular pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis. The patient's presentation, including a positive whiff test, is indicative of bacterial vaginosis, which involves anaerobic bacteria not targeted by azithromycin.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral fluconazole is an antifungal agent used to treat Candida infections, which present with thick, white discharge and pruritus. The patient's symptoms, including a thin, greyish discharge and positive whiff test, indicate bacterial vaginosis, not a fungal infection.

C) CORRECT:

Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a disruption of normal vaginal flora, leading to an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria such as Gardnerella vaginalis. This condition manifests with a thin, greyish discharge and a fishy odor, especially after intercourse, and is confirmed by the presence of clue cells or a positive whiff test. Bacterial vaginosis is treated with antibiotics that effectively target anaerobic bacteria, such as oral or topical metronidazole and topical clindamycin (see “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table).

Key learning point: Bacterial vaginosis is characterized by a positive whiff test and a vaginal pH greater than 4.5, and the appropriate treatment is metronidazole.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is used to treat gonococcal cervicitis. The patient's symptoms, including a positive whiff test, suggest bacterial vaginosis, which involves anaerobic bacteria not targeted by ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-year history of vaginal itchiness and urinary frequency. She reports that she stopped having vaginal intercourse with her husband because it became painful and sometimes caused vaginal spotting. Her last menstrual period was 14 months ago. She has a history of vitiligo and uses only topical tacrolimus ointment. Her temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. On examination, there are multiple white maculae on her forearms, abdomen, and feet. Pelvic examination reveals scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atrophic vaginitis is caused by a decrease in estrogen levels, most commonly due to menopause. Estrogen regulates the pH of the lower genital tract by acting on vaginal and cervical epithelial cells to increase acid secretion. Atrophic vaginitis is therefore associated with an increase, not decrease, in vaginal pH (typically ≥ 5; normal vaginal pH 4–4.5).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for lichen sclerosus (LS), a chronic inflammatory condition characterized by sclerosis of the vulvar dermis and most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, vulvar LS is not associated with urinary frequency and scarce pubic hair. Instead, common findings include dysuria, anal discomfort, and characteristic porcelain-white atrophic patches as well as obliteration of the labia minora and clitoris on examination. Moreover, the multiple white cutaneous spots found on examination can be attributed to her vitiligo.

C) INCORRECT:

Overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis) secondary to a decrease in vaginal lactobacilli colonization and a subsequent pH increase is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV may manifest with vaginal itchiness and dyspareunia. However, this infection is not associated with postcoital spotting, urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, and/or narrowed vaginal introitus. Moreover, BV typically manifests with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor, which is not present in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Thinning of the vaginal mucosa leading to tissue inflammation is characteristic of genitourinary syndrome of menopause, which is most commonly caused by decreased estrogen levels after menopause. Signs and symptoms in addition to this patient's urogenital findings include decreased vulvovaginal secretions and sensation of vulvovaginal dryness, loss of vaginal elasticity and rugal folds, a decreased labial fat pad, vaginal discharge, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is primarily a clinical diagnosis and treatment consists of nonhormonal vaginal moisturizers and lubricants, as well as topical or systemic estrogen therapy in more severe cases.

Key learning point: Genitourinary syndrome of menopause is caused by estrogen deficiency leading to thinning of the vaginal mucosa, resulting in dryness, irritation, dyspareunia, and urinary symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's genital symptoms raise concern for vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) (i.e., epithelial dysplasia), a precancerous lesion that is most commonly seen in postmenopausal women. However, VIN is not typically associated with urinary frequency, scarce pubic hair, or narrowing of the vaginal introitus. Instead, common examination findings include vulvar plaques, ulcers, or masses (fleshy, nodular, or warty), and lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: Scarce pubic hair, vulvar pallor, a narrowed vaginal introitus, and vaginal dryness leading to dyspareunia are consistent with genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman who is a college student comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She reports noticing white vaginal discharge despite daily cleaning of her genital area with a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is concerned about the possibility of a sexually transmitted infection. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus and is a member of the college swimming team. An intrauterine device was placed 3 months ago. On speculum examination, the vagina is erythematous and covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4, and a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.2% (4.8%–6.0%). Which one of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.

Key learning point: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus is a major risk factor for vulvovaginal candidiasis due to increased glucose availability and impaired immune defenses.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

E) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for a well-child examination. Her mother reports that for the past 3 weeks, the child has had difficulty sleeping due to pruritus in the genital area. The child has otherwise been well. She is at the 45th percentile for height and 51st percentile for weight. Vital signs are normal. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and perianal region without vaginal discharge. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Perianal cellophane-tape examination (i.e., a tape test) is the diagnostic test for Enterobius vermicularis infection. At night, female worms migrate from the colon to the anal opening, where they deposit eggs, which cause perianal and vulvar irritation and pruritus. The test is conducted by applying a transparent piece of cellophane tape to the anal opening early in the morning; any ova of Enterobius vermicularis will then stick to the tape. By pressing the sticky side of the tape against a slide, anything picked up by the tape can be examined for the presence of eggs. If the tape test confirms pinworm infection, treatment of the entire household with albendazole or mebendazole is indicated to prevent reinfection.

Key learning point: Perianal cellophane-tape examination is the diagnostic test of choice for Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection, which commonly causes nocturnal perianal and vulvar pruritus in children.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the colon

A worm is visible in the colon (green overlay). The surrounding mucosa's surface and vascular pattern appear normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Stool microscopy can be used to diagnose gastrointestinal infections with protozoans (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica) or helminths (e.g., roundworms, tapeworms, and hookworms). In helminth infection, worm eggs (ova) can be detected in the stool. Enterobiasis, however, cannot be diagnosed reliably with stool microscopy because the ova of Enterobius vermicularis are almost never shed in feces. Instead, the gravid female worms migrate to the anal opening at night and deposit the ova there.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudohyphae on a potassium hydroxide (KOH) wet mount of a perineal or vaginal swab is diagnostic of vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC). VVC may occur in pediatric patients, but it occurs more often in children who are still in diapers (candidal diaper dermatitis), which is not the case with this patient. VVC is characterized by white discharge and erythema of the intertriginous folds with “satellite” papules, neither of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Wet mount microscopy is used to diagnose suspected trichomoniasis or bacterial vaginosis. While a burning sensation in the vulvovaginal area is a typical feature of trichomoniasis, a foul-smelling, yellow-green discharge is usually present as well. Bacterial vaginosis does not commonly cause vulvovaginal pruritus and instead presents with increased gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor. The absence of vaginal discharge in this patient makes these infections unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Sexual abuse, and therefore STDs, are a concern in minors presenting with vulvovaginitis. However, in this patient, the absence of genital lesions or evidence of trauma make sexual abuse unlikely. Moreover, infections with Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea are most often asymptomatic or manifest with symptoms of cervicitis (e.g., vaginal discharge or pain, bleeding on manipulation), urethritis (e.g., urethral discharge, dysuria, and urinary frequency), or pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., fever, abdominal/pelvic pain). Nocturnal vulvar pruritus and erythema of the vulva and perianal region would not be expected.
questions.hint: Anogenital pruritus (especially at night) in a toddler or preschooler is a classic symptom of enterobiasis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of vaginal pruritus, increased vaginal discharge, and dysuria. She has not had a urinary tract infection in the past year. She uses intravaginal estriol for atrophic vaginitis. On examination, you note vulvar erythema and foamy, thick vaginal discharge, with a punctate-appearing cervix. She reports that the amount and character of her discharge have changed since her last sexual encounter, which was approximately 2 months ago. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in her evaluation?

choices.text: Perform a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid.
Recommend a diagnostic trial of not using the estriol cream.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms suggest infection with Trichomonas vaginalis, a sexually transmitted protozoan parasite that causes 5% to 50% of cases of acute vaginitis. Symptoms in women include vaginal discharge, pruritus, vaginal irritation, and a punctate-appearing cervix on examination (known as “strawberry cervix”). Infection with T. vaginalis is best diagnosed by culture or polymerase chain-reaction testing, but the diagnosis can be made by vaginal or cervical fluid microscopy and the presence of motile trichomonads; sensitivity of the wet mount is about 60%.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of vaginitis and foamy vaginal discharge is Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Performing a bacterial culture of the discharge fluid is not indicated because Trichomonas is a protozoan parasite and grows only in specialized media.

C) INCORRECT:

A diagnostic trial of not using estriol cream is not indicated, as estriol does not typically cause local inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring vaginal fluid pH is not specific for Trichomonas because pH is also elevated in bacterial vaginosis. That diagnosis should also be considered in this patient, but the next step in management is the same (wet mount microscopy) with either diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound is not indicated because this patient has clear physical examination findings consistent with her symptoms of vaginitis.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 5-day history of dysuria and vaginal itching. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. On pelvic examination, there is erythema of the vulva and vaginal mucosa, punctate hemorrhages on the cervix, and green-yellow, malodorous discharge. A photomicrograph of the discharge is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection manifests with dysuria and vaginal discharge, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, vaginal discharge in patients with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is typically mucopurulent (milky white), not green-yellow. Although Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause cervicitis, it does not result in punctate cervical hemorrhages. Also, microscopic examination of vaginal discharge would not show extracellular, flagellated protozoa, since Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a facultative intracellular bacterium.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis infection manifests with dysuria and vaginal discharge, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, vaginal discharge in patients with Chlamydia trachomatis infection is typically mucopurulent (milky white), not green-yellow. Although Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis, it does not usually result in punctate cervical hemorrhages. Also, microscopic examination of vaginal discharge would not show extracellular organisms since Chlamydia is an intracellular organism.

C) INCORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis infection manifests with vaginal discharge, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, pruritus and pain are uncommon, and vaginal discharge in patients with bacterial vaginosis is usually gray or milky with a fishy odor. This organism does not typically cause cervical pathology. In addition, microscopic examination in patients with bacterial vaginosis shows clue cells, not motile organisms.

D) CORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis infection causes trichomoniasis, which manifests with vaginal pruritus, dysuria, strawberry cervix, and green-yellow, malodorous vaginal discharge as seen in this patient. The presence of motile trophozoites on wet mount preparation confirms the diagnosis. Vaginal discharge typically has a pH > 4.5. Risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use.

First-line therapy for trichomoniasis is metronidazole for both the patient and the patient's partner(s).

Key learning point: Trichomoniasis is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis and presents with pruritus, dysuria, green-yellow malodorous discharge, a strawberry cervix, and motile trophozoites on wet mount.

E) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans infection (vulvovaginal candidiasis) manifests with vaginal discharge, pruritus, and dysuria. However, vaginal discharge in patients with vulvovaginal candidiasis is typically odorless and appears white and curdy with a cottage cheese-like appearance. In addition, microscopic examination shows pseudohyphae, not motile organisms.
questions.hint: Microscopic examination of a wet mount preparation of this patient's vaginal discharge shows extracellular, motile, flagellated protozoa.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-day history of vaginal discharge. She reports no pain or pruritus. Her menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. Her temperature is 37.3°C, pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, there is malodorous, gray vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.0. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Even though C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically odorless, white, and crumbly, and the vaginal pH would be normal (< 4.5). Additional symptoms of infection with C. albicans include intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide.

B) CORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is an anaerobic bacterium that causes bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is usually asymptomatic but may manifest with gray, malodorous vaginal discharge. There are two characteristic diagnostic findings of BV: clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria) seen on a wet mount preparation and a positive amine test (sometimes referred to as the “whiff test”). The amine test consists of applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with vaginal discharge and is positive if this causes a fishy or amine odor.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

Key learning point: Bacterial vaginosis presents with malodorous, gray vaginal discharge and clue cells on microscopy, and is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in Canada and a common cause of female infertility. C. trachomatis infection is often asymptomatic, but if discharge occurs, it is usually odorless and purulent. Clue cells are not associated with C. trachomatis, and instead it is usually diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification tests.

D) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite and one of the etiologic agents of vulvovaginitis. Although T. vaginalis would cause malodorous vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5, the discharge is usually yellow-green and frothy. Additionally, vulvovaginitis due to T. vaginalis manifests with pruritus, and the microscopic examination of the discharge would instead show flagellated protozoa.

E) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea. Gonorrhea also manifests with vaginal discharge, but the discharge is typically odorless, purulent, and creamy. The patient is also lacking symptoms of dysuria, dyspareunia, and intermenstrual bleeding, which are typical accompanying features.
questions.hint: Malodorous, gray vaginal discharge, an increased vaginal pH, and clue cells on microscopy are consistent with bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of vaginal discharge. She does not report dysuria, dyspareunia, pruritus, or burning. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She reports frequent douching after sexual intercourse. On pelvic examination, there is thin, off-white vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.1 (5.0–8.5). Wet mount examination shows that a quarter of vaginal epithelial cells are covered with small coccobacilli. Nucleic acid amplification tests of a vaginal swab are negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Treat the patient and partners with metronidazole.
Provide reassurance and schedule follow-up in one week.
Treat the patient with ceftriaxone and doxycycline.
Treat the patient and partners with ceftriaxone and doxycycline.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is indicated for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. However, as bacterial vaginosis is not a sexually transmitted infection, partner treatment is not necessary. Antibiotic treatment for both the patient and the partner is indicated in patients with infectious vulvovaginitis caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, such as trichomoniasis, which would manifest with a frothy, foul-smelling discharge with a pH ≥ 4.5 and flagellated protozoa on a wet mount.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance would be adequate if the patient did not have vaginal discharge and if bacterial vaginosis had been incidentally diagnosed during a routine check-up. Symptomatic bacterial vaginosis, however, does require treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out, and for patients who have a coinfection with both pathogens. Treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days. Gonorrhea and chlamydia can cause vaginal discharge due to cervicitis, but the discharge is typically thick and purulent. The negative vaginal swab NAAT test and the presence of clue cells on microscopy indicate a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out, and for patients who have a coinfection with both pathogens. Treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days. Gonorrhea and chlamydia can cause vaginal discharge due to cervicitis, but the discharge is typically thick and purulent. The negative vaginal swab NAAT test and the presence of clue cells on microscopy indicate a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Metronidazole is prescribed for anaerobic infections with pathogens such as Gardnerella vaginalis, the cause of bacterial vaginosis. Although sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis, this condition is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an imbalance of the vaginal flora resulting in overgrowth of Gardnerella bacteria (and a relative lack of the normally dominant lactobacilli). Another risk factor for this imbalance is vaginal douching, which this woman reports she does regularly. Bacterial vaginosis is commonly asymptomatic, but when symptomatic, individuals should receive treatment with either oral or topical metronidazole. The Public Health Agency of Canada recommends that women who are being treated for bacterial vaginosis refrain from sexual activity, as it increases the risk of relapse.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

Key learning point: Bacterial vaginosis is treated with metronidazole, and partner treatment is not required because it is not a sexually transmitted infection.
Image Description:

Speculum view of the cervix with thin gray and milky discharge
questions.hint: Based on the color and pH value of the vaginal discharge and the wet mount showing clue cells, this patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 11 weeks’ gestation presents with vulvar pruritus and thick, white vaginal discharge for the past 3 days.
